title: 2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics

last_post.content:
If you're even passingly interested in #dataviz / etc, take a few to compare these two offerings:

(1) The NYT's "2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics" https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/12/28/us/2022-year-in-graphics.html

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Even allowing for the fact that two projects are different in key ways — institutional capacity and context foremost among them — what strikes me is how flat, conventional, and superficially decorative the Tableau offerings are.

From the mid-'90s, when dataviz became more (yes) a pop phenomenon, it's struggled with how deeply its aesthetics are defined by the software tools designers relied on. They should have struggled *against* that, imo. But doing so would require a deeper understanding of the field's evolution over the last century than the obsessive recitation of names like Playfair and Minard (and, more recently, Nightingale and Dubois). The fixation on those historical figures is a classic bourgie move: using "classical" figures to signal tradition and legitimacy. (Datavizzies are way overdue for a new year's resolution to move on from that classic-rock stuff.)

I can be bitterly critical of the NYT, but its commitment to experimenting with journalistic form and content around dataviz is unparalleled. The fact that one institution could trot out its own work over just one year and *blow away* a more inwardly oriented dataviz roster says a lot.

Research on the relationships between discourse leading indicators and citations: perspectives from altmetrics indicators of international multidisciplinary academic journals | Emerald Insight https://ift.tt/9NvxMfm

I'm excited to share a brand new Story Synth format: Hexmap

Hexmap has a ton of features and custom options, learn more: https://diegeticgames.com/blog/2022/12/31/story-synth-hexmap-format.html

Hexmaps can have a "fog of war" where players can't see into hexes until they've explored closer to them.

As a designer you can specify which hexes start visible. Once a session starts, you can flip to 'facilitator mode' to swap out a hex or to change visibility.

last_post.content:
I knew someone who worked in a Toronto ER who, quite morbidly, referred to motorcyle riders as "donor cycles" -- with unsettling frequency they'd get motorcycle crash victims, often young-ish, with fatal head traumas ... but every other organ in the body in basically pristine shape

It turns out this was not, it appears, mere anecdata

title: What Can We Learn from Barnes & Noble's Surprising Turnaround?

last_post.content:
This is a great story of how Barnes & Noble’s new CEO who was hired in 2019 has turned around the company. Sales are up, it opened 16 stores this year and plans to open more next year.

The secret is the CEO really likes books and readers. So he stopped doing deals with publishers to promote their latest books & NYT best sellers and encouraged individual stores to promote books they found most interesting.

So simple yet…

The single most frustrating thing about Mastodon is that I still don't have a single Atom or RSS feed for the folks I follow from this account.

On Reddit it's at an URL that looks like this:
https://old.reddit.com/.rss?feed=SECRET&user=USERNAME

On Pinboard it's at:
https://feeds.pinboard.in/rss/secret:SECRET/u:USERNAME/

Here on #mastodon it's nowhere to be found. Adding a feed for every single person I follow to my feed reader (and manually keeping it in sync with what what my account actually follows) is not a solution that works.

title: make memory resident operations the default · Issue #4 · anticomputer/age.el

last_post.content: Seeking opinions of my cryptographer friends: epg (which age.el is a port of) by default bounces every file encryption operation through a umask 600 /tmp/gpg-* plaintext copy of the file … this feels like a terrible anti-pattern to me and my intuition is that age.el operations should be memory resident and stdio based only (streaming where needed) instead, even when considering memory dumps. Bach dedicated them to Christian Ludwig, Margrave of Brandenburg-Schwedt, hoping to get a job. But Ludwig didn't have enough musicians to play them. Bach didn't get the job. The score was left unused in the Margrave's library until his death.

'One of the reasons that it has been difficult to imagine substantial change to the peer review system may be the persistence of the myth claiming Henry Oldenburg invented peer review during the Scientific Revolution. If peer review is framed as an unchanging and time-honored system, intimately connected to the origins of modern science itself, reform seems impossible. But peer review has a far messier and more complicated history than its origin myth suggests, and its role in the scientific community has never been static. Its form and purpose have been shaped and reshaped according to what scientists needed from the practice—credibility for a new scientific society, improvement in the level of scientific literature, or assurance to patrons that money was being spent responsibly.'

https://lps.library.cmu.edu/ETHOS/article/id/29/
